facts.text: On May 9, 1952, complainant Narendra Nath Brahma was taking two carts carrying 25 Mds. of paddy for sale to Billashiparabazar along the path by the side of river Gauranga.
Complainant stopped by paddy-checking Inspector Khalilur Rahman, accompanied by appellant Faguna Kanta Nath and three others.
Khalilur Rahman demanded Rs. 200 as bribe, threatened seizure of cart and paddy, supported by appellant and three others.
Before demand, appellant and Khalilur Rahman went aside and had talks, then Khalilur Rahman demanded Rs. 200.
Complainant expressed inability, agreed to Rs. 150, borrowed Rs. 100 from Surajmal Oswal, offered Rs. 80 to Khalilur Rahman who directed to hand to appellant.
Appellant counted Rs. 80 and made it over to Khalilur Rahman.
Complainant forced to execute promissory note for Rs. 70 in favour of appellant, promising payment next day after paddy sold; Khalilur Rahman tore page from notebook, lent pen.
Complainant learnt in bazar that Happaran Rai similarly treated but paid less.
On May 11, 1952, complainant approached appellant for refund of money and return of pronote; appellant promised but did not.
On May 11, 1952, at meeting at Futkibari Middle English School with Deputy Commissioner present, complainant presented written complaint describing payment of Rs. 80 and pronote for Rs. 70.
Khalilur Rahman prosecuted under s. 161 IPC read with s. 5(2) Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947; appellant under s. 165A IPC.
Special Judge convicted both: Khalilur under s. 161 IPC (acquitted under PCA), appellant under s. 165A; sentenced to one year RI.
High Court (Deka J.) acquitted Khalilur Rahman (benefit of doubt on payment to him), upheld appellant's conviction under s. 165A.
Special Judge found fully convinced Rs. 80 realised from complainant for forbearing seizure by Khalilur Rahman, helped and abetted by appellant Faguna Kanta Nath.

legal_issues.text: Whether conviction of appellant for abetment under s. 165A IPC can be sustained when Khalilur Rahman acquitted of offence under s. 161 IPC.

petitioner_arguments.text: As Khalilur Rahman acquitted, conviction of appellant for abetment cannot be sustained on facts and circumstances.

respondent_arguments.text: Acquittal of Khalilur Rahman wrong; does not prevent conviction of appellant for abetment under s. 165A.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Dalip Singh v. State of Punjab

court_reasoning.text: For abetment under s. 107 IPC, no necessity that offence abetted is committed; s. 165A explicitly states offence punishable whether or not offence committed in consequence of abetment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Abetment by instigation or conspiracy possible even if offence not committed, but here no instigation or conspiracy proved.

court_reasoning.text: No instigation by appellant; no conspiracy as charge fails if co-conspirator acquitted (King v. Plummer, approved in Topandas v. State of Bombay).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Remains abetment by aiding: but aiding requires intention to facilitate commission of offence under s. 161, which High Court held not committed by Khalilur.

court_reasoning.text: Appellant only received money at instance of Khalilur for counting and handed back; no independent aiding of s. 161 offence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Acquittal of Khalilur means no s. 161 offence; thus no abetment by aiding.

court_reasoning.text: Dalip Singh v. State of Punjab distinguished: peculiar circumstances where Supreme Court found acquittals wrong and upheld others under s. 149; not applicable here.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cannot opine on Khalilur's acquittal as no appeal against it.

holdings.text: On facts found, with Khalilur Rahman acquitted of s. 161 IPC, appellant's conviction under s. 165A IPC for abetment cannot be upheld.

precedents_cited.relevance: Conspiracy charge fails if co-conspirator acquitted.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dalip Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Wrong acquittals do not affect other convictions in peculiar circumstances under s. 302 r/w s. 149; not applicable here.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: s. 165A punishes abetment of s. 161 offence whether or not committed; abetment defined in s. 107 (instigation, conspiracy, aiding).

statutes_cited.name: Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Khalilur charged under s. 161 IPC r/w s. 5(2); acquitted by Special Judge.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed, order of conviction and sentence of appellant set aside.

key_quotes.text: "Under the Indian law for an offence of abetment it is not necessary that the offence should have been committed."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies scope of abetment independent of principal offence commission.

key_quotes.text: "A person abets by aiding when by the commission of an act he intends to facilitate and does facilitate the commission thereof."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines abetment by aid under s. 107 third limb.

key_quotes.text: "We are of the opinion that on the facts found and circumstances established in this case and as Khalilur Rahman has been acquitted the appellants conviction cannot be upheld."
key_quotes.speaker: court
